summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team, arguing to suppress evidence obtained from the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP via a grand jury subpoena and to dismiss perjury counts (Five and Six) based on her 2016 civil deposition transcripts. The motion alleges the government made false statements to Judge McMahon to circumvent a protective order from the Giuffre v. Maxwell defamation case, violating due process.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, moving to suppress evidence from her civil depositions and dismiss perjury counts. Her 2016 depositions are the subject of the motion.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the memorandum.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the memorandum.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the memorandum.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the memorandum and signed the certificate of service.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the memorandum.

persons.name: Virginia Giuffre
persons.context: Referred to as the plaintiff in the civil defamation case Giuffre v. Maxwell, which led to the depositions at issue. Her allegations are central to the background.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Named partner of Boies Schiller Flexner LLP. The document states he approached the government in summer 2016 urging them to charge Maxwell with perjury.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the alleged sex trafficking ring. Maxwell's depositions involved questions about him and his activities.

persons.name: Judge McMahon
persons.context: Chief Judge who presided over the government's ex parte application to modify the protective order. The motion alleges the government made false statements to her.

persons.name: Judge Netburn
persons.context: Magistrate Judge who rejected a similar government request in a different civil case (Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein), criticizing the government's attempt to circumvent the protective order.

persons.name: AUSA
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney who made representations to Judge McMahon. The document alleges this prosecutor made false or misleading statements about contacts with Boies Schiller.

persons.name: Norman Mailer
persons.context: Cited in a footnote referencing a New York Times article, used in a literary analogy about false statements.

persons.name: Stephen Rex Brown
persons.context: Author of a New York Daily News article cited to support the claim that Boies Schiller urged prosecutors to investigate.

connections.description: Maxwell was questioned in depositions about her knowledge of Epstein's activities and their personal relationship, including sexual matters.
Giuffre sued Maxwell for defamation, leading to the depositions that are the subject of the perjury counts.

The motion alleges the law firm had contact with prosecutors prior to the investigation, urging them to open a case and later to charge Maxwell with perjury, contradicting government statements to the court.
Boies's firm represented Virginia Giuffre against Maxwell and, according to the motion, actively sought her criminal prosecution for perjury.
Judge McMahon issued the order modifying the protective order based on government representations, which Maxwell now challenges.

events.title: Maxwell's First Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell gave a deposition in Giuffre v. Maxwell, answering questions about Jeffrey Epstein and underage girls. Her answers form the basis for Count Five of the indictment (perjury).

events.title: Maxwell's Second Deposition
events.description: Maxwell gave a second deposition, answering highly intrusive questions about sexual activities. Her answers form the basis for Count Six of the indictment (perjury).

events.title: Boies Schiller Meets with Prosecutors
events.description: Attorneys from Boies Schiller met with AUSA and urged the opening of an investigation into Epstein and Maxwell.

events.title: David Boies Urges Perjury Charge
events.description: David Boies approached the government asking if they would consider charging Maxwell with perjury based on her deposition testimony.

events.title: First Hearing Before Judge McMahon
events.description: Government appeared before Judge McMahon in ex parte proceeding regarding subpoena to Boies Schiller. Prosecutor claimed little knowledge of the file's contents.

events.title: Second Hearing Before Judge McMahon
events.description: Judge McMahon held a hearing specifically to inquire about contacts between the USAO and Boies Schiller prior to the subpoena. The government made representations alleged to be false.

events.title: Judge McMahon Modifies Protective Order
events.description: Judge McMahon issued an order modifying the protective order from Giuffre v. Maxwell, allowing Boies Schiller to comply with the grand jury subpoena.

events.title: Settlement of Giuffre v. Maxwell
events.description: The civil defamation case between Virginia Giuffre and Ghislaine Maxwell was settled and dismissed. Confidentiality was a significant factor.

locations: Palm Beach (referenced as location of Epstein's house)
keyFacts: The motion seeks to suppress all evidence obtained from Boies Schiller Flexner LLP via a grand jury subpoena and to dismiss perjury Counts Five and Six, which are based on Maxwell's 2016 civil deposition transcripts.

It alleges the government made false statements to Judge McMahon, claiming no prior contact with Boies Schiller and that the firm did not 'foment' the investigation, when in fact the firm had urged prosecution as early as February 2016.

A protective order in the Giuffre v. Maxwell case strictly limited disclosure of confidential discovery, with no law enforcement exception, and required return or destruction of materials upon case conclusion.
Maxwell argues she relied on this protective order in agreeing to give extensive, intimate testimony rather than invoke her Fifth Amendment privilege.

Magistrate Judge Netburn rejected a similar government request in a related case, noting the government was attempting to 'side-step' protections and that Boies Schiller was 'willing (and perhaps eager)' to comply.
